chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: Abortion law should aim to reduce preventable harm by pairing respect for prenatal life with strong protection for a pregnant person’s health, dignity, and ability to obtain timely, evidence-based medical care. Rules should be clear, medically defined, and avoid criminal penalties for patients or clinicians, while guaranteeing real-world exceptions for life- and health-threatening complications, rape, incest, and cases of fatal or nonviable fetal conditions. Any regulatory framework should be matched with broad prevention and support—affordable contraception, medically accurate education, prenatal and postpartum care, childcare, and economic assistance—so fewer people face crisis pregnancies and fewer families are left without options.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: Abortion laws should be grounded in evidence-based medical standards that protect patient safety, privacy, and timely clinician judgment, while acknowledging the moral seriousness many attach to prenatal life. Policy should avoid criminalizing patients or clinicians and include clear, narrowly tailored exceptions for serious threats to life or health, rape or incest, and severe fetal conditions or nonviable pregnancies. Any limits should be paired with robust prevention and support—affordable contraception, comprehensive sex education, prenatal and postpartum care, and practical family resources—so fewer people face crisis decisions and families are better supported.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: Abortion laws should protect the life and health of the pregnant person while treating unborn life as morally serious, and they should be grounded in clear, evidence-based medical standards that let clinicians act quickly in emergencies without fear of prosecution. Any restrictions should include explicit exceptions for threats to life or serious health harm, rape, and incest, and should avoid blanket criminalization of patients or routine medical care. To reduce abortions and strengthen families, policy should expand contraception access, medically accurate sex education, prenatal and postpartum care, and practical supports like childcare, adoption services, and help for low-income parents.
